bibl.title: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, December 9, 1901

div1.p: Mabel Lazear writes about family news. She reports that she has been lobbying for her pension.

div1.head: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, December 9, 1901
div1.opener:
AC
L
Dec 9, 1901 2012 Broadway
Dear, dear Grannie -
div1.p:
You
don't know how pleased
I was to get a letter
from you. I carry it
around in my basket
of toys all the time.
and tell how the Post-
man brought me a
letter from Baltimore
Grannie.

I intended writing soon
as I had your letter
but my mother couldn't
help me she is so busy
writing herself.

I am thinking so much
about christmas and
sometimes I refuse to
go to bed because I
say Chris might come
while I was asleep.
and I know he is going
to come down the “chimne”.

Baba is learning to walk
and Mama says you
will not be surprised
that we have a new
nurse and I think I
like her better than
any we have had-
It is time for me to
go to bed - so I send
a kiss and one for Aunt
Kate. Much love from
a little boy who often
talk about you
div1.closer:
Houston.
P.S.- The P.S.- is going to
be from his mother-
You were very good
to write on the train-
I am so glad the trip
did not seem so long-
It must seem good
to be back with Aunt
Kate and in your lovely
room with every thing
so comfortable-
I should have written
long before this but
I have been busy trying
to find a good nurse
and the writing about
my pension-
Anne seemed to dislike
Houston so and displayed
so much temper that
I did not dare to leave
her around. - We were
much amused tho' aln
thought it so outrageousoutrageous
that I should ask her
to clean my room-
I have one now who
is a very quiet rather
lady like girl she
is very willing but she
seem to be rather del-
icate so it is doubtful
how long she holds out
but I feel I can trust
the children with her.
At some time in her ca-
reer she has been a
shop girl so she feels
very fine. She wheels
the Baby carriage with
a short skirt and a
black velvet had with
feathers.-
The other reason I have
not written is I am busy
with letters about my
pension - Unless one has
ever tried for a thing
of this kind they can
never imagine how many
letters one must write
to secure every scrap
of influence that they
can, then of course it
is very exhausting
work when you feel
you are appealing to all
your friends and making
a bore of yourself.
To-day and yesterday have
been much beautiful
days. - Every thing looks so
different now with the
green grass coming up.
The hills across the Bay
are so beautiful and
green -- Forgive a very
stupid letter but I was up
so much with the children in
the night I don't feel very brilliant
love to Aunt Kate & yourself from Mab
